message:
The air around it feels heavy, pressing on your chest. Whispers you can't quite hear seem to emanate from the mark, tugging at the edges of your mind.
Do you dare to touch it?

replies.text: [Touch the stone]?
[Leave it alone]?

message:
The moment your hand meets the mark, an icy jolt shoots through your body. A voice echoes in your mind, low and venomous, yet pleading:
"You...You must help me...End this torment... Seek the one I am bound to... in the place you call Crossglen..."
Your vision blurs, and a suffocating sense of dread wraps around your heart. For a fleeting moment, you glimpse a shadowed figure, writhing in agony, before it vanishes.

You stagger back, your body cold and trembling. Something has changed.

The weight of the mark grows heavier on your mind. A strange, oppressive feeling claws at your chest, urging you to leave this place and return to Crossglen.
You can't shake the feeling that something is terribly wrong there--your father, Mikhail, needs you. You must hurry.

The pull of the mark is becoming harder to ignore. A sudden wave of dizziness washes over you, and the whispers grow louder. They speak of danger, of a life lost if you do not return.
You must turn back...the time is running out. Crossglen calls. You cannot linger here.

Your steps grow heavier, the air thick with oppressive energy. The pull within your chest tightens, and the whispers now sound desperate, almost frantic.
Return to Crossglen... You cannot stay here. Your father's life is in peril. Do not test fate any longer!

You feel your breath catch in your throat, the world around you warping and twisting. The mark is burning, a cold fire coursing through your veins, clawing at your very soul.
TURN BACK NOW! Crossglen is in danger. You are too far from what matters. Return at once--before it is too late!
What's gotten into you? I'm fine, but the same can't be said for Leta. I've seen her pacing in that house of hers, muttering to herself like a madwoman. You might want to check on her.

[clearly more agitated than usual, pacing and muttering]
I am most certainly not in the mood to deal with you right now. Why can't Mikhail ever controls his kids?

replies.text: Leta, are you all right? Mikhail said you've been acting strange.

message: Strange? Who does he think he is, meddling in my life? I'm fine! Just...leave me alone!

replies.text: You don't seem fine. You've been pacing, muttering to yourself. Something isn't right.

message:
[voice trembling but defensive] Not right? Not right! What would you know about it? You don't know what I've seen, what I've felt!
[Leta pauses, clutching her head as if in pain.]

replies.text: Leta, talk to me. What's going on?

message: [voice shifting, darker and more guttural] You want to know? You want to understand? Fine. You'll see...but you won't like what you find.

message: [calm, almost welcoming] Ah, there you are. You've come back to see us, then.

Leta and Oromir's transformations are undeniable. Their peace is haunting, a reminder that not all wounds leave visible scars. The spirit may be gone, but its mark remains.

message: [frail, but confidenty] Don't mind her. She's just not use to me being so assertive.

message: So...you've seen them, haven't you? Leta and Oromir?

replies.text: Yeah, I've seen them. They're...old. What happened to them?

message: They weren't like that yesterday. I saw Leta in the fields, tending to her garden, just as spry as ever. Then this morning...well, you've seen it yourself.

message: [more skeptical, arms crossed] Old's putt'' it lightly. They look ancient, like they lived a hundred winters in just one night.
[shaking his head, grim] Not a word. Just that vacant smile of hers, like everything's fine. Oromir, though...he's got this strange look in his eye. Like he knows something we don't.
[gentle smile] Of course. Ask what you will. We owe you that much.

replies.text: Why were you affected too? Leta was the one possessed by the spirit, not you.
In your basement, I talked to a man, a farmer-looking man that is. I suspect that he is your child. But he is frightened and confused...

message: [sighs, his voice steady] Well, my child, you see, once I entered into the sacred bond of marriage with Leta, I too became bound to the spirit. Our lives, our fates, were entwined by the very vows we spoke. When she was touched by its darkness, I could not help but share in the burden.

replies.text: So, the bond between you two extended even to the curse?

message: [nods] Yes. That's the nature of true union, is it not? In love and in struggle, we are as one. Her pain became mine, just as her redemption became ours. The spirit's malice sought to age us, to wear us down. But we endure, thanks to you.

replies.text: Do you regret it? Being tied to her curse?

message: [shakes his head with a warm smile] Never. Leta is my heart, my reason for every breath. If carrying this weight was the price of sharing my life with her, then I'd pay it a thousand times over. Love isn't just about the light, it's about standing together, even in the shadows.

replies.text: [pauses] That's admirable. I hope you both find some peace now.

message: [hopeful] We will. Time may have taken its toll, but the darkness is gone. Now, we can live what remains of our days in quiet gratitude. Thank you, truly.

replies.text: I still have questions.

message: [somber, voice trembling slightly] Our son...Yes, you are right. That is Tomas. Though, to him, he may as well be a stranger to himself.

replies.text: Tomas? How could this happen to him? He's a grown man now, but he acts as if he's still that frightened child.

message: [sighs deeply, clasping his hands] When the spirit latched onto Leta, its curse didn't just affect her. It spread to everything close to her--her home, her family, even our boy. He was only two years old when it began...always holding her hand, always by her side. The spirit saw him as an extension of her, and so it bound him as well.

replies.text: But if he grew older like you both, why does he seem...stuck, mentally?

message: [sorrowful] The spirit didn't just age us. It fed on our memories, our sense of self. Tomas was too young to defend himself from its grasp. It stripped away his connection to who he was. Trapping him in fear and confusion, unable to grow in mind, even as his body aged.

replies.text: Is there any way to help him? He's terrified to leave the basement.

message: [thoughtful, but pained] Perhaps, with time. The curse is gone, but the scars it left behind are deep. He needs patience, kindness and someone to guide him back to himself. I fear we may not have the strength to do it alone.

replies.text: Yes, he needs time. I hope it works out for you three.

You've proven resourceful. Perhaps you are worthy of the knowledge I carry. The swamp holds more than muck and mire, and so do the creatures that call it home.
